inlineContent.text: An
object can hold any of the scalar types such as
, and
, as well as pointers, structures, and object
references. Use this class to work with such data types in collections (such as
and
, and other APIs that require Objective-C objects.
objects are always immutable.
The abstract
class is the public interface of a class cluster consisting mostly of private, concrete classes that create and return a value object appropriate for a given situation. It is possible to subclass
, but doing so requires providing storage facilities for the value (which is not inherited by subclasses) and implementing two primitive methods.
Any subclass of
must
override the primitive instance methods
and
. These methods must operate on the storage that you provide for the value.
You might want to implement an initializer for your subclass that is suited to the storage you provide. The
class does not have a designated initializer, so your initializer need only invoke the
method of
. The
class adopts the
and
protocols; if you want instances of your own custom subclass created from copying or coding, override the methods in these protocols.
You may also wish to implement the
method to make your subclass work well in collections.
If you need only to use
objects for wrap a custom data types or structures defined by your app, you need not create an
subclass. Instead, create a category that uses existing
methods to store and retrieve data of your custom type. For example, the code below defines a custom Polyhedron structure and creates
convenience methods to store and retrieve it:
